When the stock market indicates a new uptrend is underway, many individual investors who want to trade growth stocks and make money ironically remain skeptical.A bullish follow-through signal comes after a mostly negative period in the market, so the negative reaction is natural.The reaction may be natural but, to be blunt, it's not too smart. The investor is heeding the recent past while ignoring a signal that says present conditions have changed.What is a follow-through day? It's a bottoming signal that occurs when a major index surges in higher volume than the previous day, and at least four days from an index low.The prudent investor will make an effort to buy something on a follow-through day. The stock should be highly rated and breaking out in strong volume.What if there aren't any stocks breaking out on the follow-through? That happens, and it justifies caution.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseWhat if the stocks breaking out are stocks the investor has never heard of? That too happens, but it only means the investor hasn't been doing his or her homework.Rallies are often made of stocks that nobody but professional fund managers and devoted IBD readers have heard about.Here are several stocks that broke out on a follow-through day in recent years and the size of the gains that followed. The condition of the relative strength line, which points to outperformance vs. the S&P 500, is also noted. See the RS line painted in blue in every daily and weekly chart at Investors.com.March 1, 2010: SanDisk broke out in volume 89% above average. The RS line was at a 52-week high. The stock  rose 57% in three months. (Western Digital (WDC) acquired SanDisk in May 2016.)On the same follow-through, Power Integrations (POWI) broke out in volume 237% above average. The RS line was also at a new high. The stock gained 24% in about six weeks.Sept. 1, 2010: Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) broke out of a solid 10-week cup with handle that featured a 154.53 buy point (1)  in 124% faster turnover than usual.The accompanying weekly chart clearly shows that volume during the breakout week surged vs. the prior week, a sign of superb institutional demand. Notice how turnover was also the highest in six weeks.The RS line was at a new high. You can see historical relative strength lines and earlier charts via MarketSmith, IBD's premium stock charting and screening service. Some of the charts go back decades in time.The stock rose 70% in three months before peaking at 262.77 and dipping beneath its 10-week moving average (2) to begin a new base.June 21, 2011: Lululemon Athletica (LULU) broke out in volume 61% heavier than usual. The RS line was at a new high. Lulu advanced 25% in one month.Lululemon, a leader in premium-priced athletic apparel, is a current member of IBD Leaderboard.June 29, 2012: Anheuser Busch InBev (BUD) broke out in volume 200% above the 50-day average. The RS line was at a new high. The parent of Budweiser rose 21% in about three months.July 26, 2012: Cabela's (CAB) retook a lost buy point in volume 271% above average. The RS line was at a new high. Cabela's posted a 41% gain in a little more than two months.Oct. 21, 2014: Snap On (SNA) broke out in volume 49% above average. The RS line was at a new high. Snap On advanced 34% in 10 months.May 14, 2015: Criteo (CRTO) broke out in volume 197% quicker than normal. The RS line was at a new high. The stock gained 22% in about two months.The point here isn't that investors should fill up the portfolio with new buys on the follow-through day. Instead, an investor should buy one or two stocks and see if they continue to act well. Avoid the extremes of either jumping in too aggressively or refusing to test the waters at all.And keep track of the relative strength line. It's an important indicator of strength.(A version of this column was originally published on Sept. 4, 2017. When people mention the building sector, many folks think of homebuilders. Sometimes, though, such associations can be misleading. It's not enough to ask which of the 33 sectors are doing well. You have to know where the strength is within the sector.That's why IBD breaks the market into 197 industry groups.Homebuilders, for example, have a Relative Strength line that has been moving sideways since August. (The RS line measures performance vs. the S&P 500. A rising line points to outperformance; a falling line to laggard action; and a sideways line to performance in line with the S&P 500.)Meanwhile, the building sector has been in the top five among 33 sectors in that same period.So where is the real strength?Nine industry groups make up the building sector. Only three show rising RS lines over the past few months. Hand tools' RS line is at a 52-week high. Within the group, the top three stocks are Toro (TTC), Snap-on (SNA) and Stanley Black & Decker (SWK).Of those three, Toro has delivered the best earnings growth in the most recently reported quarter. Earnings jumped 121% on a 16% increase in revenue.Toro's Boss unit boosted results — it wrapped up the acquisition of Boss, a designer and maker of snowplows and salt and sand spreaders, in November 2014.The stock is in the 5% buy zone above a 74.22 buy point. Wood products' RS line is just off a recent high. The industry group has four stocks, and only two posted earnings gains in the past two quarters.Universal Forest Products (UFPI) grew earnings 19% and 31% in Q2 and Q3, respectively. Revenue rose 8% and 7% in the same quarters.The stock, though, fell 8% Dec. 8 on DA Davidson's downgrade from neutral to underperform. Universal is thinly traded, with a daily average volume of $12 million.April initial public offering Enviva Partners (EVA) posted a profit of 4 cents a share in Q2 vs. a loss of 8 cents a share in the year-earlier quarter. In Q3, earnings rose 108% to 27 cents a share. Revenue jumped 60% and 53% in the same quarters.Enviva is a master limited partnership involving wood pellets, which customers use to replace coal in power generation. The manufactured homes and RV group has enjoyed a rising RS line, though the line recently faded.The group has six stocks, but only one has delivered double-digit earnings growth in two or more consecutive quarters.Patrick Industries (PATK) grew EPS at least 27% in each of the past six quarters. Sales growth varied from 14% to 31% in the same six quarters.The stock has two drawbacks: A late October breakout failed, eventually driving the stock under its 50-day line and testing the 200-day line. Also, the stock is thinly traded, with a daily average dollar volume of about $5 million.

Stanley Black & Decker crushed third-quarter earnings views and topped revenue expectations as growth in its consumer do-it-yourself segment surged in both North America and Europe.
Third-quarter earnings per share increased 13% to $1.55 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting EPS of $1.44.

The power-tool manufacturer tightened its full-year adjusted EPS outlook range to $5.52-$5.58 from $5.50-$5.60, with the midpoint of $5.55 remaining the same. It's still above the current consensus estimate of $5.53.
Revenue in Q3 rose 5.2% to $2.902 billion, passing estimates for $2.872 billion.
Shares climbed 2.2% to 88 on the stock market today.
In Q3, the consumer do-it-yourself (CDIY) segment captured 50% of sales, which grew 9% to $1.45 billion. Organic growth in North America was up 12% and in Europe was up 11%.

Stanley Black & Decker (SWK) pointed to tool demand driven by new products, strong outdoor-product volume and expanded retail offerings as responsible for the growth in North America. An expanded retail footprint and new product introductions led to market share gains in Europe, the company said.

The Stanley Black & Decker industrial segment's sales increased 5% vs. a year ago. The industrial and automotive repair (IAR) business had organic sales growth of 7%, with strength in both North America and Europe. Organic growth for the infrastructure business was down 1% due to "the expected slowdown in on-shore oil & gas activity and project delays due to the geopolitical situations in Russia, Ukraine and the Middle East."

The security segment's sales fell 3%, though higher prices partially offset the drop by 1%. Europe led the decline, sliding 7% due to lower installation and recurring revenues, Stanley Black & Decker says. But Europe's order rates were up by high single digits for the quarter.

"CDIY organic growth accelerated in the third quarter, contributing to record operating margin, and Industrial posted strong results as a result of robust sales and operating leverage in Engineered Fastening and IAR," said James Loree, president and COO.

"Companywide, emerging markets growth was positive for the quarter despite a choppy and slowing environment. Our midprice-point product launches position us for continued share gain in these somewhat slower markets."
The Building-Hand Tools industry group is ranked No. 106 out of the 197 groups that IBD tracks. Stanley Black & Decker holdd the No. 2 spot within the group, behind competitor Snap-on (SNA).

Snap-on handily topped Q3 forecasts when it reported last week. It earned $1.76 a share, rising 23% from a year earlier and beating analysts' views by 33 cents. Revenue rose 14% to $859.9 mil, also beating views.
Snap-on shares rose 0.2% to 128.05.

Shares of Stanley Black & Decker (SWK) plunged as much as 18% in massive volume Wednesday after it reported weaker-than-expected Q3 earnings and full-year guidance.
The toolmaker said the U.S. government shutdown, weak emerging markets and slow security business prompted it to revise its full-year earnings outlook downward.
The company now sees 2013 EPS of $4.90-$5, excluding charges, well below consensus of 18 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $5.39 a share.

Meanwhile, Q3 earnings per share slid 2.1% to $1.37, vs. analyst projections of $1.38. It was the third quarter in a row of lower earnings for Decker. Revenue dipped 1% to $2.76 billion, missing Wall Street's $2.82 billion target.
Stanley Black & Decker shares were down 13% in midday trading in the stock market today.
Among other toolmakers, Snap On (SNA) eased less than 1%, while maintenance and lawn care equipment maker Toro (TTC) touched an all-time high and was trading up 1%.

Stanley Black & Decker saw particular weakness in its security business, which makes products ranging from door locks to automatic doors and security systems for consumers, schools, hospitals and industry.

Chief Financial Officer Donald Allan said in a statement that "year-to-date performance of our Security business has created pressure on our results which has, along with lower organic growth expectations with certain businesses and geographies, caused us to revise our full year 2013 earnings and free cash flow outlook."

Sales growth is an important metric for any company, as it is a vital part of growth projections and influences strategic decision-making. By monitoring this key metric over multiple time periods, one can clearly understand a company’s growth trend.Sales growth is essential to justify the fixed and variable expenses incurred to run a business. Low revenues lead to unprofitability of business and disappointing financial results. Stagnant companies may generate near-term profit but can’t rev up enough growth to attract new investors.Also, in a growing economy, lack of sales growth most likely denotes that the company is not gaining market share over its competitors. The first Fathers Day was said to be celebrated on Jun 19, 1910 in Spokane, Washington. Sonora Smart Dodd is credited with originating the idea while listening to a Mothers Day sermon in 1909. Sonora, along with her five siblings, was raised by her father after the death of her mother. She thought it would be nice for him to know how special he was to her. While she aimed to have the day celebrated on the day her father passed away (June 5th), it is reported that she did not provide the organizers with enough time to make the necessary arrangements and it was subsequently deferred to the third Sunday in June.

In 1924, President Calvin Coolidge proclaimed the third Sunday in June as Father's Day and President Nixon, in 1972, established it as a permanent national observance. And that concludes your brief history lesson.

Chicago-based Jones Lang LaSalle, Incorporated is a leading full-service real estate firm that provides corporate, financial, and investment management services.  The company caters to corporations and other real estate owners, users, and investors worldwide.  A broad real estate product and service range, and extensive knowledge of domestic and international real estate markets, enable Jones to operate as a single-source provider of real estate solutions.Jones Lang LaSalle was formed following the 1999 merger of LaSalle Partners, Incorporated, and Jones Lang Wootton companies.  Its diverse operations span more than 100 markets in approximately 34 countries across the globe.  The company divides its business into two primary segments:  Investor and Occupier Services (IOS), and Investment Management.  The IOS segment (which produced $1.035 billion in revenue in 2004) is sub-divided into three units:  Americas, with its strong focus in implementation and management services, providing 35.9% of revenue; Europe, where Jones Lang has a strong capital markets transaction business, providing 42.8%; and Asia-Pacific, generating 21.3% of revenue, at year-end 2004.  These units collectively manage owned or leased real estate in international locations; represent tenants for the acquisition and disposition of properties; provide leasing to agencies; service corporate properties; manage property; and provide valuation services.The Investment Management (IM) division generated 12.7% of revenue in 2004, but contributed more than 34.5% to total operating income of $92.2 million in 2004.  IM, with $26 billion under management, provides real estate investment-management services, mainly to institutions, corporations, and affluent individuals.  Its prominent customers include the New York City Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Microsoft, and Procter & Gamble.  The company runs its global investment management business under the LaSalle Investment Management brand.  Jones Lang LaSalle usually invests its clients funds in publicly traded securities of real estate investment trusts (REITs), and via acquisition and development joint venture structures. Sell-off After First-Quarter 2005 Announced Overdone

First-quarter 2005 results were roundly met with disapproval from investors, as the stock traded off nearly 20% during the day results were announced.  While volatility like that should be considered before making an investment in a small-cap, fairly illiquid security like Jones Lang, we believe the selling was clearly overdone.  It is true the companys first-quarter 2005 loss was wider than results reported in the prior years first quarter (-$0.27 per share in 1Q05 versus -$0.20 per share in 1Q04), the first quarter is not only the seasonally weakest time of the year for most real estate services companies, Jones Lang used the slowdown to increase investment in its segments, which positions the company more favorably longer-term.  We believe much of the sell-off was due to momentum investors bailing on news they do not understand.  Likely, they saw Jones Langs peers (Trammell Crow and CB Richard Ellis) report positive first quarter earnings, and panicked.  With a business that is typically back-end loaded (fourth quarter is generally the strongest period for the company), we recommend taking advantage of the sale and adding to positions. Improving Economies in U.S. and Europe Driving Margin Improvement in IOS

The U.S. economy has regained its footing and should improve further in 2005, which should drive increasing demand for real estate services.  Jones Lang is already starting to see improvement, as evidenced by the 230 basis point operating margin improvement in its Americas IOS segment in 2004, versus 2003.  We are forecasting continuing improvement in margins in 2005.  With more than 2 million new jobs expected to be created in 2005, we believe the company should be able to grow its Americas business in the mid-double-digits, and see operating margin expansion in the 100-150 basis point range.We believe out-performance for Jones Lang could derive from its Europe IOS segment, which has lagged in performance due to a slower economic recovery, and to rising interest rates in Europe that are hurting the companys transactions business.  We expect strong revenue growth, but are forecasting relatively flat operating margins in this business, due to increasing competitiveness and declining transaction volumes.  We believe, however, that our margin assumption (at 4.1% for 2005) could prove conservative, particularly if leasing and management services can become a bigger proportion of revenues. Strong Growth Prospects for Investment Management Business

With recent strong real estate returns in the capital markets (according to NAREIT, publicly traded real estate companies delivered a total return of 30.4% for 2004, versus 10.9% for the S&P 500 over that same time period), we believe Jones Langs investment management business should see increasing interest from investors looking to capture strong real estate returns.  With interest rates expected to increase at a measured pace, and real estate fundamentals improving across all property types, we believe real estate investors should continue to see returns that outpace the broader market.  As such, we expect strong growth in funds under management in 2005 for Jones Langs IM division.  In the first quarter, assets under management grew nearly $2 billion, from $24 billion at yearend 2004 to $26 billion currently.  As the company continues to monetize funds that have reached target performance metrics, given the strong equity and private market performances of real estate investments, we are forecasting that incentive fees could increase by at least 50% in 2005, from the $20 million the division generated in 2004, even if the $20 million is well-above normalized fees.  Incentive fees are highly accretive, given that they are not budgeted to cover fixed costs, and generally only trigger higher variable bonus payments for managers. Outsourcing Driving Strong Demand for Real Estate Services in Asia Pacific

U.S. companies continue to offshore tasks overseas to India and China.  We believe that Jones Lang is uniquely positioned to capture the increasing demand for space, be it call-centers, manufacturing and distribution facilities, or office space, via its brokerage services and capital markets operations in these countries.  Additionally, China continues to be the best growth market in the world, and we believe that despite recent interest rate increases by its central bank, China should continue to pace the world in economic expansion.  With very little infrastructure in the country to support expected growth, we believe demand for real estate services should be increasing long-term, which should serve to accelerate growth for Jones Lang in 2005 and beyond.  Moreover, the company is seeing strong transaction-based fee growth, particularly in its hotel business, and that should continue into 2005, as interest rates remain low for most Asia Pacific countries.  We particularly like prospects in the Japanese market, where transaction volume should increase. Re-iterating our Buy Recommendation

Given improving real estate fundamentals and economic growth around the world, we believe shares of Jones Lang will continue to outperform the broader market.  Jones Lang reported such great fourth-quarter results, we are affirming our cash flow estimate for 2005 of $2.35 per share.  We are forecasting the same EBITDA for 2005 as in our prior report; however, the company has more shares outstanding, and as such, we are tweaking our EBITDA per share estimate to $4.65 per share.  We are reaffirming our Buy recommendation, but are lowering our price target to $42.00 per share, based on a 10.2x enterprise value to EBITDA multiple we believe the company merits. Sell  Snap-on (Ticker: SNA)

Snap-on  is a global provider of professional tools, equipment, and related solutions for technicians, vehicle service centers, original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), and other industrial users. Products include a broad range of professional hand and power tools; tool storage; vehicle diagnostics and service equipment; business management systems; equipment repair services; and other tool and equipment solutions. The company operates through four reportable business segments: the Snap-On dealer group, the commercial & industrial group, the diagnostics & information group, and the financial services segment. In 2004, Snap-on generated net sales of over $2.3 billion, of which 44% was derived by the Snap-On dealer group, 41% from the commercial & industrial group, 12% from the diagnostics & information group, and 3% from the financial services segment.Over the past few years, management of Snap-on has focused on delivering a more predictable and consistent financial performance as well as enhancing shareholder value. To this end, the company implemented its Driven to Deliver strategy in 2001, which has resulted in an increased focus on customer relationships and business processes. The company has also looked to improve asset utilization by rationalizing production through plant closures and making more effective use of working capital. The company has also become more customer-driven, invested in new products, and increased brand awareness. In addition, Snap-on is returning value to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends.While we believe that Snap-on is steadily progressing towards a turnaround, the pace of change remains below both managements and investors expectations. As a result, managements earnings expectation for fiscal year 2004 deviated substantially from an original forecast at the beginning of the year of $1.80 to $2.20 per diluted share to an actual reported $1.40 per diluted share.  Further, we do not expect the company to achieve the high end of its original guidance until 2007. In our view, management has substantial work to do in order to generate the type of margin improvement investors now expect from the company. In line with this, management indicated that the company will take an additional $20 to $25 million in restructuring-related charges in fiscal year 2005 as it looks to further reduce costs and improve operating efficiencies.  As such, we continue to believe that the companys valuation remains well ahead of the current stage of recovery.We expect near-term results to continue to be hampered by rising raw material and freight costs and disappointing organic growth for the dealer group in the U.S. While the company has worked to rationalize asset utilization and manufacturing costs, production relocation has led to previously unanticipated operational inefficiencies and higher freight costs. We expect these costs, combined with rising raw materials costs, to largely offset the benefits associated with the headcount reduction and the closure of production facilities. In addition, we expect higher spending in 2005 related to the companys initiative to transition to a build to order production process for its higher volume products.  We also expect disappointing organic growth and a decline in the average number of dealer vans to hold back company-wide organic sales growth in 2005. Finally, we are somewhat concerned about the departure of the companys CEO and the replacement by a member of the board.  Given our negative outlook for the company, and the current high valuation, we maintain our Sell rating. 1Q 2005 Earnings Scorecard  S&P 50069% (of the companies) exceeded estimates
